Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Applying the Tools of Physics--From the Cosmos to the Living Cell"
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign provides twelve undergraduate students each summer the opportunity to participate in research on topics in biological physics, high-energy physics, nuclear physics, acoustical physics, astrophysics and condensed matter physics. In addition to participating in research with an experienced team of mentors, the REU students will gain knowledge of and practice technical communications, research collaboration and networking, and responsible conduct of research. They are given career guidance and advice on applying for graduate school and graduate research fellowships. By the end of the program, every student will have presented the results of the work in a mid-term talk, a final talk, and a research paper.

This REU site will have a number of broader impacts with its focus on providing research opportunities to undergraduates to help prepare them for future science, technology, engineering, and mathematics careers. The site has a strong plan to recruit undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in physics and from non-research institutions. The project is informed by an on-going evaluation and there is a plan to disseminate successful undergraduate research practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this project, 41 talented undergraduate students undertook independent hands-on research projects. They learned how to grown and analyze exotic superconductors, wrote code that was used in data analysis for high-energy physics experiments at Fermilab and the Large Hadron Collider, and built detectors for nuclear physics and observational cosmology experiments. One student was able to combine her love of physics and music by doing sophisticated acoustical studies of the alto horn and the euphonium. Another combined her interest in physics and passion for tennis by carrying out a sophisticated analysis of the inelastic collisions between racket and ball. 

Two international students, one from Ghana and one from Hong Kong who were not supported by the National Science Foundation, participated in the program to add an international dimension to the experience for the US students. 

Every student gave at least three talks and wrote a final paper on his or her research project and received detailed oral and written feedback on their work.

Programmatic activities included a four-day orientation "boot camp" during the first week of the eight-week sessions that covered lab safety, responsible conduct of research, tutorials on scientific software and literature searches, and discussions of how to select and apply to graduate programs in physics and related disciplines. Additional workshops were held during the program and included presentations on campus safety, sexual harassment and gender bias, creating and presenting scientific posters, giving science talks, and writing scientific articles for publication. At least two students per year received support to present their work at national conferences.  

A total of 21 faculty participated in the program; several took students all three years of the project and most participated in at least two of the three years. Faculty ranged from senior professors who are members of the National Academy of Sciences to assistant professors who are building their labs, but all were committed to the success of their students. In addition, each student was paired with a senior graduate student or postdoctoral researcher who served as a mentor, providing an additional layer of support for the student.

Great efforts were made to recruit a diverse cohort, with special emphasis given to including students from smaller colleges, those from backgrounds historically underrepresented in physics, and first-generation college students. In all, 56% of the participants were women, and 85% came from small colleges or universities with limited research programs in physics. In terms of demographics, 12% were Hispanic, 15% were African-American, and 39% were first-generation college students.  Of the students who have graduated from college, more than 70% have enrolled in graduate programs in physics, computer science, materials science, or electrical engineering. Three are working as engineers (software and mechanical engineering) and two are working as high-school physics teachers.
